Council Member Foster moved to spread the Invocation in full upon the Record.

A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to requiring the department of citywide administrative services to create and submit a written report regarding eligible lists.
Items.ActionText: A motion was made by  that this Introduction be Approved by Council.
Items.MatterName: Citywide Administrative Services to create and submit a report regarding elgible lists.

Items.Title: Resolution decrying the sexual violence and killing of women in Ciudad Juarez, Mexico over the past ten years, calling upon the Comptroller of the City of New York to develop and enforce procedures, short of disinvestment, that ensure that corporations receiving New York City pension funds respect the basic human rights of their employees and calling on the appropriate authorities in Mexico to take steps to end the killings in Ciudad Juarez.
Items.AgendaNote: Amended and Adopted by the Committee on Cultural Affairs, Libraries & International Intergroup Relations
Items.MinutesNote:
Pursuant to Rule 8.50 of the Rules of the Council, the Public Advocate (Ms. Gotbaum) called for a voice vote.  Hearing no objections, the Public Advocate (Ms. Gotbaum) declared the Resolution to be adopted.

Adopted unanimously by the Council by voice-vote.
Items.MatterName: Decrying the sexual violence and killing of women in Ciudad Juarez, Mexico

Items.Title: Resolution supporting the “Berlin Declaration,” a document summary of the second international conference on anti-Semitism recently held by the Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe.
Items.AgendaNote: Adopted by the Committee on Cultural Affairs, Libraries & International Intergroup Relations
Items.MinutesNote:
Pursuant to Rule 8.50 of the Rules of the Council, the Public Advocate (Ms. Gotbaum) called for a voice vote.  Hearing no objections, the Public Advocate (Ms. Gotbaum) declared the Resolution to be adopted.

Adopted unanimously by the Council by voice-vote.
Items.MatterName: Supporting the "Berlin Declaration"

Items.Title: Resolution strongly denouncing the crimes committed against civilian populations in the western region of Darfur and the actions of the government of Sudan in connection with those crimes, and urging the government of the United States to take immediate action to support the implementation of a United Nations multi-national peace-keeping force and humanitarian relief effort to end the reign of terror that exists in that region.
Items.AgendaNote: Amended and Adopted by the Committee on Cultural Affairs, Libraries & International Intergroup Relations
Items.MinutesNote:
Pursuant to Rule 8.50 of the Rules of the Council, the Public Advocate (Ms. Gotbaum) called for a voice vote.  Hearing no objections, the Public Advocate (Ms. Gotbaum) declared the Resolution to be adopted.

Adopted unanimously by the Council by voice-vote.
Items.MatterName: Denouncing the crimes committed against civilian populations in the western region of Darfur .

Items.Title: Report of the Committee on Finance
A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to the establishment of the Myrtle Avenue Brooklyn business improvement district.
Items.ActionText: A motion was made by  that this Introduction be Approved by Council.
Items.MatterName: Myrtle Avenue BID, Brooklyn

Items.Title: Report of the Committee on Governmental Operations

A Local Law to amend the charter and the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to the requirements of the campaign finance program for city elections, the requirements of transition and inauguration entities for candidates elected to the offices of mayor, public advocate, comptroller, borough president, and member of the city council, participation in the New York City Campaign Finance Program by self-funded candidates, the debate program, and limiting the use of government resources during an election year.
Items.MatterName: Requirements of the campaign finance program for city elections.

Items.Title: A Local Law to amend the charter and the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to application of contribution limits of the New York City Campaign Finance Program to all candidates for the offices of mayor, public advocate, comptroller, borough president, and member of the city council, and prohibiting candidates from accepting contributions, loans or security for such loans from corporations.
Items.MatterName: Selected requirements of the NYC Campaign Finance Program.

Items.Title: A Local Law to amend the charter and the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to application of the public disclosure requirements of the New York City Campaign Finance Program to all candidates for the offices of mayor, public advocate, comptroller, borough president, and member of the city council.
Items.MatterName: Application of selected requirements of the NYC Campaign Finance Program.

Items.Title: Resolution recognizing October 12-20, 2004 as National Bone and Joint Decade Awareness Week, and encouraging the promotion of education and greater awareness of Fibrodysplasia Ossificans Progressiva in the City of New York.
Items.AgendaNote: Adopted by the Committee on Health
Items.MinutesNote:
Pursuant to Rule 8.50 of the Rules of the Council, the Public Advocate (Ms. Gotbaum) called for a voice vote.  Hearing no objections, the Public Advocate (Ms. Gotbaum) declared the Resolution to be adopted.

Adopted unanimously by the Council by voice-vote.
Items.MatterName: National Bone and Joint Decade Awareness Week - October 12-20, 2004

Items.Title: Resolution urging New York State to allow persons who are in dating relationships and experience abuse to petition for orders of protection in Family Court.

Pursuant to Rule 8.50 of the Rules of the Council, the Public Advocate (Ms. Gotbaum) called for a voice vote.  Hearing no objections, the Public Advocate (Ms. Gotbaum) declared the Resolution to be adopted.

Adopted unanimously by the Council by voice-vote.
Items.MatterName: Allow persons who are in dating relationships and experience abuse to petition for orders of protection in Family Court.

Items.Title:
Introduction & Reading of Bills

Discussion of Resolutions

INTRODUCTION AND READING OF BILLS

Resolution urging the New York State Legislature to increase funding for Naturally Occurring Retirement Community Support Service Programs (“NORC-SSPs”) to meet the growing needs of seniors who wish to remain in their own homes as they age.
Items.ActionText: This Resolution was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Aging due back on 10/28/2004.
Items.MatterName: Increase funding for Naturally Occurring Retirement Community Support Service Programs (“NORC-SSPs”)

Items.Title: Resolution urging the New York State Legislature to adopt a bill that establishes a minimum staffing level requirement in nursing homes.
Items.ActionText: This Resolution was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Aging due back on 10/28/2004.
Items.MatterName: Adopt a bill that establishes a minimum staffing level requirement in nursing homes.

Items.Title: Resolution calling upon the Congress of the United States to pass S.2968, the “Emergency Flu Response Act of 2004”, introduced on October 8, 2004, by a bipartisan group of Senators, which would address the crisis created by the current shortage of flu vaccine.
Items.MatterName: “Emergency Flu Response Act of 2004”

Items.Title: Resolution honoring the special skills of the medical staff at The Children’s Hospital at Montefiore who performed surgeries for Carl and Clarence Aguirre, honoring the bravery of these two young children and their mother, Arlene Aguirre, and expressing the enthusiasm of this City and the world in their successful recovery for a bright future.
Items.MatterName: Honor the special skills of the medical staff at The Children’s Hospital at Montefiore.

Items.Title: Resolution calling upon the New York City Department of Education to hold open for public use, outside of school hours, playgrounds located on school property.
Items.ActionText: This Resolution was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Education due back on 10/28/2004.
Items.MatterName: Dep't of Education to hold open for public use, outside of school hours, playgrounds located on school property.

Items.Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to limiting the issuance of notices of violations for litter during certain times.
Items.MatterName: Llittering to limit the issuance of notices of violations during certain times.

Items.Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to establishing a joint task force on sidewalk maintenance.
Items.ActionText: This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Transportation due back on 10/28/2004.
Items.MatterName: Establishing a joint task force on sidewalk maintenance.

Items.Title: Resolution calling upon New York City and New York State to fund the Summer Youth Employment Program at Fiscal Year 2002 levels.
Items.MatterName: NYC & NYS to fund the Summer Youth Employment Program at FY'02 levels.

Items.Title: Resolution calling upon the Mayor and the State to negotiate and reach a firm agreement with respect to the Summer Youth Employment Program in advance of the budget process so that youth participate in the SYEP at maximum possible enrollment levels, keeping in mind that as recently as two summers ago there was sufficient funding for the employment of 37,869 young people; and further calling upon the Mayor to include requisite funding in the Preliminary and Executive Budget proposals, in order to ensure the timely and effective implementation of the SYEP.
Items.ActionText: This Resolution was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Youth Services due back on 10/28/2004.
Items.MatterName: Mayor and the State to negotiate funding for the Summer Youth Employment Program in advance of the budget process.

Items.Title: Resolution recognizing April 25, 2005 to April 29, 2005 as National Playground Safety Week.
Items.MatterName: National Playground Safety Week, April 25-29, 2005

Items.Title: Resolution calling upon the appropriate committee of the Council of the City of New York to hold a hearing on the practice of Department of Sanitation personnel not to attempt to serve summonses by personal delivery as required by the New York City Charter prior to serving them by mail.
Items.MatterName: Hold hearing on the practice of Dep't of Sanitation personnel not to attempt to serve summonses by personal delivery.

Items.Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to requiring the reporting of statistics relating to students receiving special education services.
Items.ActionText: This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Education due back on 10/28/2004.
Items.MatterName: Requiring the reporting of statistics relating to students receiving special education services.

Items.Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to re-inspections, increased penalties for false statements and additional remedies for failure to correct violations under the housing maintenance code.
Items.ActionText: This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Housing and Buildings due back on 10/28/2004.
Items.MatterName: Re-inspections, increased penalties for false statements and additional remedies for failure to correct violations under the housing maintenance code.

Items.Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to the posting of amendments to building permits.
Items.MatterName: Posting of amendments to building permits.

Items.Title: Resolution calling upon the Council of the City of New York to support passage of S. 139, the Climate Stewardship Act, in the United States Senate, which would provide for a program of scientific research on abrupt climate change and accelerate the reduction of greenhouse gas emissions in the United States by establishing a market-driven system of greenhouse gas tradeable allowances that could be used interchangeably with passenger vehicle fuel economy standard credits.
Items.ActionText: This Resolution was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on State and Federal Legislation due back on 10/28/2004.
Items.MatterName: Support passage of S. 139, the Climate Stewardship Act.

Items.Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to prohibiting or restricting the advertisement and promotion of tobacco products to protect children.
Items.MatterName: Prohibiting or restricting the advertisement and promotion of tobacco products to protect children.

Items.Title: A Local Law to amend the charter of the city of New York, in relation to authorizing the Civilian Complaint Review Board to receive, investigate, hear, make findings and recommend action upon complaints by members of the public regarding the policies and procedures of the police department including, but not limited to, the unsanitary conditions at police managed facilities, the failure of the police to address medical or other health related needs of arrestees and inappropriately excessive detention periods.
Items.MatterName: Civilian Complaint Review Board

Items.Title: Resolution urging Governor Pataki, in coordination with Mayor Bloomberg, to request the $4.45 million Congress made available to New York State for the Project Liberty Program in the FY 2005 Homeland Security Appropriations bill which was signed into law by the President, in order to continue the provision of counseling to personnel, families and retirees of the New York City Fire Department and the New York City Police Department who were seriously traumatized by the September 11, 2001 terrorist attacks in New York City, and thereby making more funds available to support the continuation of Project Liberty to meet the needs of the general public.
Items.AgendaNote: Mental Health, Mental Retardation, Alcoholism, Drug Abuse and Disability Services
Items.ActionText: This Resolution was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Mental Health, Mental Retardation, Alcoholism, Drug Abuse and Disability Services due back on 10/28/2004.
Items.MatterName: Mayor Bloomberg, to request the $4.45 million Congress made available to NYS for the Project Liberty Program in the FY 2005 Homeland Security Appropriations bill.

Items.Title: Resolution supporting the use and acceptance of the Mexican Consulate’s Matrícula Consular identification card by the city of New York as valid identification for Mexican immigrants living in the United States.
Items.MatterName: Use and acceptance of the Mexican Consulate’s Matrícula Consular identification card.

Items.Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to limiting the acquisition of a rifle or shotgun to one per ninety-day period.
Items.ActionText: This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Public Safety due back on 10/28/2004.
Items.MatterName: Limiting the acquisition of a firearm to one per ninety-day period.

Items.Title:
By Council Member Moskowitz:
Pursuant to Rule 11.20(b) of the Council and Section 20-226(g) of the New York City Administrative Code, the Council resolves that the action of the Department of Transportation approving an enclosed sidewalk café located at 60 West 57th Street, Borough of Manhattan, Council District no. 4, shall be subject to review by the Council. (Application no. 20045009 TCM.)
Items.ActionText: The Public Advocate (Ms. Gotbaum) put the question whether the Council would agree with and adopt such motion which was decided in the affirmative by the following vote:
Items.MatterName: Sidewalk Cafe, 60 West 57th Street, Manhattan (20055009TCM)

Items.Title: Resolution calling upon the State Legislature to immediately introduce and adopt, and the Governor to sign, legislation which would provide an additional sales tax exemption week on all clothing and footwear costing up to $110 per item from November 22, 2004 to November 28, 2004, for the area of Manhattan bounded by 30th Street in the south, 36th Street in the north, Park Avenue in the East and Tenth Avenue in the west.
